conclusion: Consider factors of power, collision, and deflection based on the image and given information.
Car 'A' enters from the lower right corner and moves towards the left, as indicated by the arrow.
Car will encounter several colored blocks (squares) as it moves leftward. These blocks are stationary and will act as obstacles.
When the car collides with a block, it will likely be deflected. The deflection angle and distance will depend on the car's speed and the angle of impact.
Car's power (speed) will determine how far it can travel after each collision.
Car will first encounter the red block. A collision here will likely deflect the car upwards or downwards, depending on the angle.
Subsequent collisions with other blocks will continue to change the car's direction.
Car will eventually lose momentum due to repeated collisions and friction with the surface.
Car will stop near the last block it collides with, depending on the cumulative effect of deflections and energy loss.

Second collision likely with the green or orange block, further changing its direction.
Subsequent collisions continue to reduce speed and change direction.
Given the layout and assuming moderate power, the car will likely stop near the central area, possibly close to the green or blue blocks, after multiple deflections and energy loss.
